subsc: Sub-national government administration,Primary education,Tertiary education,Central government administration

abstracts.cdata!:
The Second Primary Education
            Project's outcome is rated as satisfactory,
            sustainability as highly likely, institutional development
            impact as modest, Bank performance as satisfactory, and
            borrower performance as satisfactory. The sharp devaluation
            of Mexican peso in 1994-95 led to a reduction in project
            costs, which in turn led to a partial cancellation of the
            Bank loan in 1995 and a complex project restructuring
            exercise which was successfully completed in 1997. As a
            result, project objectives were expanded and two new
            components were added. The key lessons learned include: A
            clear and consistent policy framework is key to the
            achievement of project objectives. Project ownership and
            continuous participation of stakeholders greatly enhance
            project design and implementation. Effective targeting is
            essential to optimize the impact of compensatory programs.
            Precise output indicators should not obviate the need for
            outcome indicators. The results of the measurement of
            education quality must be analyzed and disseminated.
            Updating teaching skills through in-service training can be
            more effective when combined with classroom-based technical
            assistance. Community participation greatly improves the
            cost-effectiveness of school infrastructure investments but
            requires appropriate design and technical supervision.
            Community agreements for the maintenance of school buildings
            need to be properly funded.
